choices.A: Change the network type to point-to-multipoint

choices.D: FortiGate is configured with graceful restart, and will exit graceful mode, if the network topology changes.
choices.A: In an HA cluster, FortiGate devices will keep the OSPF routes in their routing table to avoid traffic interruption during an HA failover.
choices.C: After the default 40 seconds wait time, the OSPF neighbors will resume communication with the restarting router.
choices.B: The OSPF neighbor that receives the grace link-state advertisement (LSA) will enter into helper mode.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A and B are correct as per the OSPF chapter on Graceful restart mode.

Selected Answer: AB
A,B correct answers

Selected Answer: AB
Page 176 of Study Guide.
A - Yes - Graceful restart mode helps you avoid traffic interruptions if the router goes offline. 
B - Yes - the neighbors that receive the grace LSA will enter into helper mode.
C - No - communication resumes after 120 seconds, by default (not 40)
D - No - routers configured with graceful mode will NOT exit graceful mode in the case of a network topology change.

questions.question_text:
An administrator configured the following command on FortiGate.

config router ospf
set restart-mode graceful-restart

Which two statements correctly describe the result of the above command? (Choose two.)

choices.C: FortiGate uses the CN information from the Subject field in the server certificate.
choices.A: FortiGate uses the first entry listed in the SAN field in the server certificate.
choices.B: FortiGate closes the connection because this represents an invalid SSL/TLS header.
choices.D: FortiGate uses the SNI from the userâ€™s web browser.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Study Guide Page 238. Uses the CN field instead of the SNI to obtain the FQDN. Strict is when it closes the connection.

Selected Answer: B
7.2 Study Guide page 238
Strict: if the SNI does not match the CN or SAN fields in the returned servers certificate, fortigate closes the coneection.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct, strict mode causes FortiGate to close the connection if the SNI does not match the CN or SAN fields as per the FortiGuard and Security Profiles chapter on SSL Certificate inspection and SNI check

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit, which shows an SSL certification inspection configuration.

SSL certification inspection configuration

//IMG//


While testing, the administrator updated the ssl-ssh-profile configuration with the command set sni-server-cert-check strict.

The administrator found that the server name indication (SNI) does not match either the common name (CN) or any of the subject alternative names (SAN) in the server certificate.

With respect to the set sni-server-cert-check strict command, which action does FortiGate take?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
A - wrong IKEv2 fragmentation is done in IKE layer
B - wrong The reassembly timeout default value is 15 seconds
C - Correct
D - Correct

Selected Answer: CD
7.2 Study Guide page 300

Selected Answer: CD
Page 300, maximum number of ikev2 fragments 64 and Only some IKEv2 packets are fragmentable: AUTH, CREATE_CHILD_SA and some INFORMATIONAL

Selected Answer: CD
C and D are correct, only certain IKEv2 Packets are considered as Fragmentable as it happens at the IKE layer. The maximum number of IKEv2 fragments are 64 and the reassembly timeout is 15 seconds.

Selected Answer: CD
page 300 , maximum number of ikev2 =64, default timeout =15 sec

choices.C: Only some IKE version 2 packets are considered fragmentable.
choices.A: IKEv2 fragmentation is performed at IP layer.
choices.D: The maximum number of IKE version 2 fragments are 64.
choices.B: The reassembly timeout default value is 30 seconds.

questions.question_text: Which two statements about IKE version 2 fragmentation are true? (Choose two.)
Which two statements about IKE version 2 fragmentation are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A: Only some IKEv2 packets are considered fragmentable: AUTH, CREATE_CHILD_SA, and some INFORMATIONAL.
B: Reassembly timeout is 15 seconds, not 30 seconds.
C: Check the question and the Study guide. IKEv2 fragmentation does happen in the IP layer, and IKEv2 fragmentation "SUPPORT" happens at the IKE layer instead of the IP layer.
D: The maximum number of IKEv2 fragments is 64, not 128

Selected Answer: AC
A and C are correct. See page 300 in the Enterprise Firewall 7.2 Study Guide:

A: Only some IKEv2 packets are considered fragmentable: AUTH, CREATE_CHILD_SA, and some INFORMATIONAL. 

C: Page 299 in Study Guide: If fragmentation occurs at the IP layer, during the IKEv2 connection, it is possible that payload sizes may exceed the IP MTU and packets get fragmented. 
Now, on page 300, it is indeed stated that fragmentation is performed on the IKE-layer to solve the issues raised with Fragmentation on the IP-layer. This is supported on IKEv2 with IKEv2 fragmentation support: 
config vpn ipsec-phase1-$interface
set ike-version 2
set fragmentation enable | disable
set fragmentation-mtu $size

Bottom line; somewhat tricky question, at least with regards to it requesting two answers, and i definitely isn't B or D.

Maximum number of IKEv2 fragments = 64 (for reassembly)
The Answer is A and C
only one anwer is right . A study guide page 300

Selected Answer: AC
A and C are correct

Selected Answer: AC
Answer should be A only, but it requires 2 answers so it's AC ...
p300 :
A correct : "Only some packets are considered fragmentable."
C wrong : "With IKEv2 fragmentation support, the fragmentation occurs at the IKE layer instead of the IP layer." BUT if set fragmentation is set to disable, then answer C could be right ....
BD wrong : "The maximum number of IKEv2 fragments are 64, and the reassembly timeout is 15 seconds."

Selected Answer: A
only A is correct imho
A -> yes, study guide p. 300
B -> reassembly timeout 15 sec, not 30
C -> nope, fragmentation is done at IKE layer, not IP! (To not be blocked by firewalls)
D -> nope, the max number is 64 (p. 300 study guide)

comments.content: regarding C: it could be right if ikev2 fragmentation support is not configured
